the Antarctic. It has kind of snowballed
from there in a sense.

1273.72.text:
I think something that
I try to do when I speak to the media is to,

1277.35.text:
I think, stay very honest with the data and
to—I kind of see myself as being a journalist

1283.03.text:
in the sense that I want to report the facts
of what's happening without any kind of interpretation.

1288.33.text:
I don't want to tell you if you should care
about the facts or if you should care about

1293.67.text:
what should change; what I want to do is to
present the facts of how the ice is changing.

1298.81.text:
Then it is up to you to believe whether it's
climate change or whether should you change

1302.96.text:
carbon emissions to have an effect on this.
I don't want to tell you this. I want to be

1307.20.text:
independent and give you the facts and then
let people decide themselves what to do.

1311.07.text:
I think you have to toe a fine line but—I
mean, of course, you want to provide the message

1315.87.text:
of what's happening and you have your own
personal opinions in terms of, I think, what

1320.03.text:
a scientist should do in terms of trying to
reduce the effects of climate change. I think

1326.14.text:
it's important to be independent and to give
the facts of what they are without that kind

1330.75.text:
of emotional interpretation they can have
sometimes and let people decide themselves

1334.99.text: what to do with those facts.

1342.44.text:
I think really the biggest questions, which
have really come to fore in the last decade or so

1347.66.text:
is how the big ice sheets are changing. It's
really amazing that in the 1990s when I was working

1352.97.text:
on my PhD, we knew virtually nothing about
Greenland or Antarctica. We hadn't even imaged

1357.11.text:
the interior parts of Antarctica because it was so far South.
So I think the most interesting scientific issues

1363.16.text:
that we've seen really develop in the last
decade or two are the changes to the big ice sheets.

1367.95.text:
That's really coming from a development
of remote sensing. In the 1990s, we hardly

1372.89.text:
had any satellite images with the big ice
sheets, particularly in the interior parts.

1377.27.text:
Since the late 1990s and early 2000s, we've
had a dramatic increase in how we can actually

1380.83.text:
understand how those big ice sheets are changing.
That's really been—kind of given us that

1386.40.text: big-scale perspective which we need to understand how that much ice is changing.

1389.76.text:
In the past, you had to rely on, kind of, spot
measurements from a few locations. To get

1395.43.text:
that really big regional picture, you need
remote sensing. That's been the huge development

1399.09.text:
that we've seen in the last decade or two
decades. That's really revolutionized what's

1404.15.text:
our understanding of how these big ice sheets
are changing.

1411.76.text:
I think what I tell to people who don't accept
science—I haven't spoken to many people

1418.40.text:
who don't really accept the science. I think
people don't always accept the interpretations

1422.20.text:
from the science. I think it's very hard,
it's almost impossible to argue that we aren't

1427.14.text:
seeing climate change. I mean, when we look
at, really, every weather, every climate station

1431.12.text:
in the world, when we look at the glaciers,
the permafrost, it's all telling us the same

1434.18.text:
thing that climate is changing. I think the
question that I come up against sometimes

1438.16.text:
is, "Well, should we care about it? I mean,
the world has gone through—for sure, it

1442.87.text:
has gone through similar temperature changes
in the past. The world's done fine in the

1446.90.text: past. Why should we care about it today?"

1448.59.text:
I don't see much debate about the fact that
things are changing. I think it's more of

1454.08.text:
a question of whether we should care about
the fact that they are changing. I think in

1459.71.text:
a sense, as a scientist, you want to keep
it simple and just present the facts without

1463.80.text:
that kind of emotional interpretation. I think
if you present the facts and make it clear

1468.61.text:
that it's not one single weather station that's
shown you one pattern, if you talk about all

1474.38.text:
the different sources of information that
we have, whether it's from sea ice, glaciers,

1479.27.text:
permafrost, snow, weather stations, all kinds
of records then—they're all pointing in

1487.08.text:
I find that when people ask me about climate
change: Is climate change real? Then frequently,

1491.57.text:
you can ask people living in Ottawa, for example,
and ask them, "Well, were the winters that

1496.23.text:
you experienced when you were a kid different
from what we see right now? Did you skate

1500.87.text:
for longer? Was there more snow?" I think
everyone says, "Yes, there was." I mean, clearly,

1505.72.text:
the winters that people experience today are very
different to what they were 30, 40 years ago.

1509.66.text:
I think when you put it in that personal perspective
and people think back and tell stories of

1515.65.text: these awful winters that happened 50 years ago and snow drifts the size of houses and this kind of stuff,

1519.69.text:
when you put it on that personal
perspective for them, then they can start

1523.59.text: to understand that things really are changing.

1530.54.text:
People
argue, "Well, we've seen the climate be much

1533.24.text:
warmer in the past." Then the big difference
today is that, in the past, there weren't

1539.16.text:
7 billion people living on the planet. There
weren't huge cities next door to the ocean

1543.56.text:
that are built for a sea level that existed
hundreds of years ago pretty much.

1546.00.text:
If you think of New Orleans, New York, London,
Venice, all these cities around the world

1551.35.text:
with millions of people living inside them
are designed for past climate, in a sense.

1556.19.text:
Yes, for sure, we've seen climate change in
the past, but there weren't seven billion

1560.92.text:
people living on the planet when that happened.
I think that's the difference today is that,

1564.51.text:
in a sense, it doesn't even matter what causes
the climate change. Maybe you want to argue

1570.15.text:
that it's all natural change, but still the
climate is changing, and so it's going to have impacts.

1575.18.text:
Whether you care about the
cause of it, it's still will have those impacts

1577.60.text:
down the road for things like changes in global
sea level.
